newsitem.title: UK: GKN up on court ruling, defence stocks rally.
newsitem.headline: GKN up on court ruling, defence stocks rally.

text.p: Shares in GKN Plc rose in early trade on Friday as a U.S. court reduced damages awarded against its Meineke Discount Muffler unit, while defence stocks rose as fears eased of a tougher UK government line on military exports.
GKN was up 23p or 2.3 percent at 10.07-1/2 stg by 0742 GMT, the biggest gainer in the FTSE 100 index. British Aerospace Plc rose 22-1/2p at 12.55 stg and Smiths Industries Plc firmed 14p at 765.
GKN said it was appealing against a U.S. court judgement even though damages against its Meineke unit had been reduced to $390 million from $600 million.
The damages relate to a claim by Meineke franchisees that the group had mishandled and mis-spent millions of dollars charged for advertising.
News of the award sent GKN shares sharply lower when first announced last December -- and again in March when an initial $398 million award was raised to $600 million.
Separately, defence stocks benefitted from a newspaper report that the UK government would not block sales of military equipment to Indonesia.
The Independent newspaper said Foreign Office sources said export licences granted last December would not be revoked -- easing concerns of a general clampdown on military exports.
The Indonesian orders included armoured cars made by GKN, while Bae plans to sell Hawk jets to the regime.
Analysts said the reduction of the award was not a major surprise since it in effect took the situation back to the original award last December.
"This is not a particularly significant development," said one analyst, who asked not to be named.
"We all knew that the company was going to launch an appeal and this just confirms that the franchisees who waived their rights can't get back in...it is really a non-entity of a statement."
Analysts also noted that defence stocks had come under pressure in recent sessions, partly on worries that the recently-elected Labour government may block some defence exports.
They said Labour would still probably take a tougher line in some instances deals but added that major export deals were unlikely to be under threat.
"I would be very sceptical that this would make a major impact," said another analyst. "Twenty thousand jobs in the UK would be at risk, is that what the government wants to happen?"
